page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 20 June
It may please yo
r
. H it is advertised out of
Gueldres,
that
e house of
Blienbeecke
is surrendred to
e Ennemie.
It had bin two monethes besieged, and valiantly defen-
ded: but through devision among those w
t
in, it was
soddainly given over. Which was grievously taken by
S
r
Martin Schincke
, both for
at it was his owne posses-
sion, and because he was comming w
t
his forces to raise
e siege. Howbeit in this place
e losse is not greatly
accounted of. It is certified hither, but not tho-
rowly c
o
firmed,
at
Count William of Nassau
hath newly
surprised
e sconce of
Fernsum,
by
Delfsiel,
in
e terri-
torie of
Groeninghen,
a place of great advantage, in res-
pect of annoieng those
at enter
e river by Delfsiel.
The Ennemie draweth every day newe forces towardes
e siege of
Hoesden:
but hath hitherto exploited nothing.
The Governo
r
Mons
r
Fauma
, who is in it, is reputed an
expert Captaine, and wanteth nether victual nor men
for a long time. Of
Mons
r
Carons
negotiation
I leave
e report to suche letters, as he himself hath sent yo
r
H. He hath taken a great deale of paines to procure
e release of
Deventer,
and
e restitut
o
n of
President
Aisma
, and those of
Leiden.
But I feare it still, w
ch
I feared at first,
at he will reape litle fruite of his pain-
full endevo
rs
. For I could never perceave
at these men
would doe any thing but
iniquis conditionibus
. The
messengers sent from hens to
e
Scottishe kinge
about the
mater of Steward, are newly returned, but have made
no relation as yet, of
e K. intertenment and answear.
I have heerw
t
sent yo
r
H. a copie of those particular
pointes, whiche I have proposed to
e
Generall states
, in
my
L. Willughbies
cause. I doe not perceave that
they goe about to make answear, and I am half persua-
ded,
at they will passe it over in silence. For I finde
by
e c
o
ference w
ch
I have had w
t
my L heretofore
and by
M
r
Gilpins
informac
o
ns, and by other good
intelligence,
at they will never be able to justifie
those pointes w
t
sufficient proofe. I purpose after
a while to calle upp
o
them for an answear, whiche
if
ei shall refuse to deliver unto me, according to
fol.299v
the charge whiche I receaved from my
LL.
of
e coun-
cell, I am by writing to require a publicke Act of their
refusall: whiche direction I minde to folowe: unles I
be countermaunded, or willed by yo
r
H. to take an other
course. In whiche respect it may stande w
t
yo
r
H.
favo
r
to impart
e copie of those Articles, whiche I have
proposed, to
e LL of
e councell, and to signifie
in suche convenient time, as yo
r
H shall thinke fitte,
if other order shalbe taken.
And so I take my
humble leave of yo
r
H. From
e Hage.
June 20. 89. Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
